title: Low rates contribute to housing 'turnaround,' despite risks: CBA
text:
Commonwealth Bank chief executive Matt Comyn said that low interest rates had contributed to a "turnaround in some established housing markets," while acknowledging that falling rates posed challenges for the bank and its customers.

Mr Comyn told a relatively subdued annual general meeting that customers who relied on interest payments from savings balances had seen their income decrease, and that lower interest rates were a feature of the global economy.

But he added that "housing prices are now rising in Sydney and Melbourne after having fallen for 18 months, and there are encouraging signs that the market has stabilised".

The International Monetary Fund slashed Australia's economic growth forecast to 1.7 per cent overnight and warned of a synchronised global slowdown amid the US-China trade war.

The CBA chief executive acknowledged the "uncertainty about the outlook for global growth," and praised the impact of the government's tax cuts.

"There are signs that the government’s recent tax cuts for many Australian families have supported the economy at this time," he said.
description: CBA chief executive Matt Comyn says there are encouraging signs that the housing market has stabilised with house prices in Sydney and Melbourne rising.
